title: 106_hr1399
content: The "Fairness for Legal Immigrants Act of 1999" allows certain alien pregnant women and children to be eligible for Medicaid under the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996. The "Fairness for Legal Immigrants Act of 1999" permits states to waive certain Medicaid eligibility requirements for pregnant women and children who are lawfully residing in the United States, including battered aliens. This includes pregnant women during pregnancy and up to 60 days postpartum, as well as children defined under the plan. Additionally, the Act specifies that affidavits of support do not apply to benefits provided under a state waiver. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to exclude benefits provided under a state waiver from the definition of 'means-tested public benefits'. Conforming amendments are made to various sections of the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996. Amendments are made to various sections of the Immigration and Nationality Act and the Social Security Act to exclude benefits under state waivers from 'means-tested public benefits'. The effective date of these amendments is retroactive to the enactment of relevant acts in 1996. Optional eligibility of immigrant children for SCHIP is addressed in Section 3. Section 405 of the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 is amended to allow states to waive certain eligibility requirements for child health assistance under the State child health plan for children lawfully residing in the United States, including battered aliens. This waiver is contingent upon the state already having an election in place for a specific category of individuals. The amendment allows states to waive eligibility requirements for child health assistance under the State child health plan for children lawfully residing in the United States. This waiver is contingent upon the state having an election in place for a specific category of individuals. The effective date for the amendment is October 1, 1997. SEC. 4. OPTIONAL ELIGIBILITY OF CERTAIN MEDICALLY NEEDY ALIENS FOR MEDICAID. Optional eligibility for certain blind or disabled medically needy aliens admitted after August 22, 1996, under the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996. Individuals who are considered blind or disabled under the Social Security Act may be eligible for medical assistance. The amendment allows certain medically needy aliens to receive supplemental security income benefits or State supplementary payments. States have the option to waive certain eligibility requirements for medical assistance for aliens requiring a certain level of care. Certain Level of Care.--States have the option to waive certain eligibility requirements for medical assistance for aliens who were lawfully residing in the United States on August 22, 1996, and are residents of a nursing facility or require a similar level of care. The effective date of this amendment is retroactive to the enactment of the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996. Eligibility of certain aliens for SSI. Eligibility for SSI is outlined for aged aliens lawfully residing in the United States on August 22, 1996, and for blind or disabled qualified aliens who entered the United States after that date. Eligibility for SSI is outlined for aged aliens lawfully residing in the United States on August 22, 1996, and for blind or disabled qualified aliens who entered the United States after that date. Exceptions are made for certain blind or disabled aliens regarding the 5-year ban under the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996. The amendments made by subsections (a) and (b) are effective for benefits payable after the enactment of this Act, specifically for certain blind or disabled aliens under the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996. Enforcement of affidavits of support for eligible individuals is detailed in section 213A of the Immigration and Nationality Act. The Nationality Act amendments are effective for benefits payable after the enactment of this Act, based on applications filed on or after the date of enactment. SEC. 6 amends eligibility for food stamps for legal immigrants residing in the US on August 22, 1996. SEC. 7 addresses eligibility for legal immigrants suffering from domestic abuse. Expansion of eligibility for benefits to battered immigrants under the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996. The Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 is amended to include benefits for immigrants who have experienced battery or cruelty, to alleviate harm or prevent future harm. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made regarding sponsor deeming under the Act. Conforming amendments are made to the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 regarding sponsor deeming and the definition of "family" for battered immigrants accessing federal public benefits. The Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 is amended to include provisions for domestic violence situations involving spouses, parents, children, and individuals covered by civil or criminal domestic violence statutes. The Act is amended to include provisions for domestic violence situations involving spouses, parents, children, and individuals covered by civil or criminal domestic violence statutes. The amendments apply to Federal means-tested public benefits provided on or after the date of enactment of this Act.
